title: What Does “WRD” Mean? (Plus, When & How to Use It)

steps.title: “WRD” means “word” and is used to express agreement with someone.
steps.content: “WRD” means “word” and is used to express agreement with someone. It’s the shortened version of the slang term “word,” which is another way of saying “true” or “I agree.” If you say something and the other person responds with “WRD,” it means they approve of what you’re saying. [1] X Research source Sometimes, “WRD” can be used to acknowledge what someone said, sort of like saying “okay” or “cool.” It communicates that you heard the other person or received their text.

steps.title: Reply with “WRD” to agree with someone’s statement.
steps.content: Reply with “WRD” to agree with someone’s statement. Whether they’re spilling the tea or sharing an unpopular opinion, respond with “WRD” to convey that their comment is true. It means that you approve of their words and have the same opinion as them. [2] X Research source Them: “Last night was a movie.” You: “WRD.” Them: “Cool ranch > nacho cheese Doritos.” You: “WRD.”

steps.title: Respond with “WRD” to confirm that you heard someone.
steps.content: Respond with “WRD” to confirm that you heard someone. Rather than leaving them on read or replying with a boring Tapback, use “WRD” to politely affirm their message. It’s one of the easiest ways to end the conversation or move onto another topic . Them: “The party is at 10 PM.” You: “WRD.” Them: “I’m going to the grocery store.” You: “WRD.”

steps.title: Follow up with an exclamation point to express your enthusiasm.
steps.content: Follow up with an exclamation point to express your enthusiasm. Are you super, super excited about something in the future? Reply with “WRD!” to emphasize how much you’re looking forward to it. Them: “We're grabbing pizza on Friday.” You: “WRD!” Them: “Free to go shopping this weekend?” You: “Yeah!” Them: “WRD! Let’s hit The Grove 🛍️”

steps.title: Add a question mark at the end of “WRD” to convey shock or disbelief.
steps.content: Add a question mark at the end of “WRD” to convey shock or disbelief. If your friend shares major news or an unbelievable story, reply with “WRD?” to make sure you heard them correctly. It’s another way of saying “what?” or “really?” which may encourage them to give you more details. Them: “I passed the bar!” You: “WRD?” Them: “Yesss 👩‍⚖️” You: “Congrats!!!!” Them: “I’m officially off the market 💍” You: “WRD?” Them: “YES 💒👰💐🔔”

steps.title: Send “WRD” to show indifference or anger toward someone.
steps.content: Send “WRD” to show indifference or anger toward someone. If someone says something out of pocket or texts you a rude message, reply with “WRD” to brush them off. It’s the equivalent of rolling your eyes, especially if you end it with a passive aggressive period. Them: “You need to turn your music down.” You: “WRD.” Them: “I heard you talking on the phone until 4 AM.” You: “WRD.”

steps.title: Weird or weirdo
steps.content: Weird or weirdo Some people use “WRD” as the shortened form of “weird” or “weirdo,” but it totally depends on the context of the conversation. If someone is acting strange or mentions a crazy conspiracy theory, for example, you could reply with “WRD” if you think they’re being a little odd or funny. Them: “Did you hear him using a baby voice to ask her out?” You: “Yeah, he’s WRD.” Them: “They didn’t talk to each other the entire night. Something is up…” You: “That’s WRD. Maybe they broke up?”

steps.title: Wireless reading device
steps.content: Wireless reading device If you’re talking to someone about books or reading in general, “WRD” may refer to a wireless reading device, like a Kindle or NOOK. This meaning isn’t very common, so ask the other person for clarification if you’re confused by what they’re saying. “What’s the best WRD?” “Don’t you read on a WRD?”

steps.title: Water resources department
steps.content: Water resources department When it comes to environmental protection, the acronym “WRD” stands for “water resources department.” This may be a program that tracks the quality of water, investigates sources of pollution, or develops strategies to tackle water quality threats. steps.title: World Radio Day
steps.content: World Radio Day Established by the United Nations General Assembly in 2012 as a UN International Day, February 13 is World Radio Day (WRD). It highlights the remarkable history and power of radio as a medium for democratic discussion. steps.title: White Ribbon Day
steps.content: White Ribbon Day Also known as International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, White Ribbon Day was created by a group of Canadian men in 1991 in response to the École Polytechnique Massacre of 1989. The campaign is a pledge that asks men to “never commit, condone, or remain silent about violence against women and girls.” [5] X Research source

steps.title: Facts
steps.content: Facts “Facts” is another way of saying “agreed.” People use it to express agreement with someone, especially if they share a controversial opinion or hot take. [6] X Research source Them: “ Friends is overrated.” You: “Facts.”

steps.title: LMK
steps.content: LMK The acronym “LMK” is short for “let me know.” It’s a popular way to ask someone for their response or decision, especially if you’re trying to finalize plans with them. [7] X Research source “LMK if you’re coming to the party!” “If you have any recommendations for a new series, LMK!”

steps.title: IKR
steps.content: IKR “IKR” stands for “I know, right?” which is a rhetorical question that people use to express agreement with someone. Think of it as another way of saying “I know exactly what you mean.” [8] X Research source Them: “I can’t believe the movie was 3 hours long?” You: “IKR?! It felt a lot shorter…”

steps.title: FR
steps.content: FR It’s the shortened version of “for real,” which is another way of saying “seriously?” or “really?” People usually send “FR” when they’re unsure whether someone is joking over text. [9] X Research source Them: “I just got a ticket…” You: “No way, FR?!” Them: “Yeah…for being too sexy 😜” You: “Staphhhh 🤣”

steps.title: Bet
steps.content: Bet “Bet” is a popular slang expression that means “okay” or “definitely.” It conveys that you heard the other person, so use it to confirm plans with friends or validate their ideas or statements. [10] X Research source Them: “Do you want to grab dinner on Saturday?” You: “Bet. What kind of food are you feeling?”
